Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a crocodile. Fragment. This handmade terracotta crocodile holds a fish or cake in its mouth. Buff to yellow surfaces, probably a white preparation for paint. Red-brown Nile silt with grey core and abundant organic, mica, limestone and quartz inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

There are a few, rare, crocodile figure parallels from Naukratis (Gutch 1899, 96, no. 336; Boston 86.426; Fitzwilliam E.224.1899; Ashmolean AN1896-1908-E.4789). These may be from stand-alone figures, or fragments from vessels. The style and materials are consistent with Late period, or possibly very early Ptolemaic figurines made in the Nile Delta. Crocodile figures were made in Egypt since at least the Middle Kingdom (Petrie Museum UC6678, from Coptos; UC7193-7 from Lahun) and subsequently (Petrie Museum UC42136, unprovenanced). Such figures were produced for festivals and dedicated at sanctuaries. However, see also parallels dated 'Roman' (Dunand 1990, no. 885-6, see also 887-8). Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 96, no. 336)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.319) (Phase 3)
